articleContent.title: Chord: Dominant 7b5 in D (Shape: E)
articleContent.content:
# Chord: Dominant 7b5 in D (Shape: E)

### Brief Presentation
The Dominant 7b5 chord in the key of D has the root note D, major third F#, diminished fifth Ab, and minor seventh C. Played using the E shape, it has a unique and tense sound that can add color and tension to your music.

### Notes and Intervals
- D (Root)
- F# (Major Third)
- Ab (Diminished Fifth)
- C (Minor Seventh)

### Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7b5 chord is commonly used in jazz and blues music to create tension that resolves to the tonic chord. It has a dark and mysterious quality due to the combination of the diminished fifth and minor seventh, adding an element of dissonance to your compositions.

### Genre and Usage
This chord is often used in jazz standards, blues progressions, and funk music. It can be found in both chord progressions and as a passing chord to add flair and tension to a musical piece.

### Songs
Here are three songs that use the Dominant 7b5 chord in D (Shape: E):
1. **"All Blues" by Miles Davis** - This jazz classic features the Dominant 7b5 chord in various progressions, adding depth and color to the harmonic structure.
2. **"The Thrill is Gone" by B.B. King** - This blues standard uses the Dominant 7b5 chord to create a melancholic and soulful atmosphere in the chord progressions.
3. **"Cissy Strut" by The Meters** - In this funk instrumental, the Dominant 7b5 chord is used to add funkiness and tension to the groove, showcasing its versatility in different musical contexts.
